program.title: Studying the Occurrence Rate of Planets Orbiting White Dwarfs with the GMT Method
program.abstrakt: Detecting planets at 1 < a < 5 AU orbiting white dwarfs (WDs) and studying their occurrence rate would shed light on the evolution of planetary systems during the post-main-sequence phase of stellar evolution and the ultimate fate of Earth. Currently, there is no measurement of the occurrence rate of WD planets. We propose 7.5 hrs of the Gemini GSAOI with the GeMS to measure the flux for the host stars for 16 microlensing planetary systems and constrain them to be WDs or main-sequence stars. We will form a statistical sample including ~5 WD planets if the occurrence rate of WD planets at 1 < a < 5 AU is the same for main-sequence stars and measure the occurrence rate of WDs for the first time. Our project can serve as the foundation for a future GMT microlensing project by training scientists in the essential skills to carry out GMT AO imaging.

program.title: Investigating helium enhancement of RR Lyrae stars in NGC 6441 and NGC 6388
program.abstrakt: NGC 6441 and NGC 6388 are two unique Galactic bulge globular clusters that host a rich population of RR Lyrae variables in spite of their high metallicities. RR Lyrae in these clusters exhibit unusually long periods, which was suggested to be due to a helium enhancement that increases their luminosities and in turn their pulsation periods. However, the multi-epoch NIR observations of NGC 6441 showed that their RR Lyrae Period-Luminosity relations (PLR) are in excellent agreement with the predictions of pulsation models for normal helium content. Interestingly, the RR Lyrae PLR in NGC 6388 provide a strong hint of helium enhancement, but also exhibit larger scatter compared to NGC 6441 variable. Therefore, we propose GeMS-GSAOI high spatial resolution time-series imaging of the central region of NGC 6441 and NGC 6388 to obtain high-precision near-infrared photometry of their central RR Lyrae stars. These observations will probe likely helium enhancement in RR Lyrae populations in these twin clusters by a direct comparison with the predictions of the pulsation models. If the differences between the two cluster RR Lyrae stars are confirmed, that would challenge the stellar pulsation models.
